Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Mining Spec> What is the total Supply and when is that Supply expected to be reached?

Half of the reward issued is done through the proof of stake system but is that reward the same as the mining reward?

Do you have to have a certain amount in order to participate in the proof of state if so how much? what would be the expected reward? Are there different tiers or does the amount change over time?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @NWhiskeyTango I would prefer you don't leave too, and I'm sorry to make a judgement about who was being rude. Perhaps I missed something. I'd delete my statement, but I think it's fair to you to leave it, so it might justify your response a bit. I just feel pretty bad when I see that we "decided" to change. We didn't decide to have either GPUs or secret mining FPGAs. The original algorithm stood up well to GPUs, but it was too small in size, had some things that could be optimized significantly on hardware and was simply missing enough barriers to equalize FPGAs. we've learned. I can promise that I never decided to add them, but you could argue that Chris, as a developer, decided to write the GPU miner, and we didn't change the algo for that. Chris did a great job on the GPU miner, and it didn't stop CPU mining altogether. FPGAs were a very different story, and it is time to adjust.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the new Algo will likely be CPU only at first, was designed to leverage every strength of CPUs, especially where they are weaknesses of hardware, and is expected to bring GPUs much closer to CPUs, as Chris doesn't think they will yet be slower. We've closed every known hole for algo-specific optimization of hardware. Short of testing on an FPGA, we are optimistic as is reasonable, and rather than take some additional steps to cut them off, which will make things worse, IMO, when they come back, we believe the new algo has a very good chance of making them a non issue and reinvigorating CPU mining. Since we don't yet have GPU or FPGA, we can only go by opinions of experts we know. On FPGA, due to the money involved, only an actual implementation optimized by someone really good will give us the final answer.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <NWhiskeyTango> Yes i agree. I try to keep up. Crypto Rich interviews and frequent discord visits.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cragorn> @Gloryman Yea, that might be, but I can't say for sure. Also, the point was that this puts close to 23TH/s on one entity. The other FPGAs could be more decentralized if they are on private hands.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> @Cragorn agreed

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Gloryman> The $500 one.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> when I say "likely CPU only", I actually do hope that Chris finishes the GPU miner, and I think it will be a challenge to beat CPUs if it is possible. as far as net hash, I am quite sure we will go back to numbers from the earlier days (still with the 51% attack immunity of VerusPoP). The new algo, if it ends up being final, is significantly slower on CPUs as well because it's just doing more. We'll get more benchmarks on different CPUs before I put out numbers, as it should advantage the newest CPUs over older ones as well, which is our strategy to defend against bot-nets.

Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> If anyone is considering using the AAcoin staking feature, I would be very cautious. AAcoin is a very new exchange, and very little information is available about it(At least in English). English support is basically non-existent. That coupled with the fake trading activity on the site means I will be staying away.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Fyi some of our community members are presently holding some significant VRSC on the exchange and we definitely would not have given AAcoin a shout out if we felt at all uncomfortable with their comm or actions.  They are very new yes, and keeping your coins on any exchange is always a risk.  As for the slow withdrawals, I also experienced this and it‚Äôs unclear why they take a long time to approve withdrawals.  Bottom line, always proceed with caution when dealing with a third party...we haven‚Äôt seen any significant reason to distrust these guys more than any exchange however.

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> They claim to be a team of people from large Chinese companies, but provide no details. Could be former mailroom clerks for all we know. I trade on some really sketchy exchanges, and this one sets off alarm bells.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> At the least they could put the effort into hiring a competent proofreader to clean up the translation, and also making sure their links all work. That's just amateur.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <runningwithbeer> AACoin looks shady to me. But I realize I might have some bias against chinese crypto anything. Long story...  I hope they are on the up and up. But I'm staying out...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> All I know is that they seemed interested in the project from the time they contacted us. They don't seem to be doing that for all projects, which you might expect if they were more of a scam, and they are the first exchange or pool to build automated staking support. We don't know them more than working with them here, but they seem technically capable, and based on their interest, they integrated and listed Verus for free before even asking for the 25K, which was earmarked for promotion. The trading bot was interesting. They acknowledged it, explained it, and they have turned it off in response to the Verus community. I hope they are trustworthy as they seem when communicating, and it would be great if we could have the ability to know. Lifetime 1% staking fee is a reason to at least register, IMO.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> Not saying they are a scam. Just sharing personal experience and observations. In my unprofessional opinion, people should tread carefully.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> Still wondering about the possibility of hardware wallet staking at some point in the future

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> You should always be concerned with how you keep your cryptocurrency. You're responsible, being your own bank and all. You have every reason to be careful. I wouldn't go so far to call everything unreliable to be scam though. I'm too cautious and  wouldn't dare to take the risk in my own current situation, but my understanding is that there are gamblers out here/there that would throw themselves at these kind of things. And AACoin are great for making it available either way, just be careful to engage if that's not your thing.
